This game is incredible. I first played it at launch in 2013, and after suffering through Battlefield 6, and promptly uninstalling it. I decided to revisit Battlefield 4. I couldn’t be happier that I did. Returning to this masterpiece reminded me exactly why I’ve been a Battlefield fan since the days of Battlefield 1942.

The Levolution in BF4 is far superior to its modern counterpart. The level design, the pacing, and most importantly, the gunplay all eclipse the bland, overproduced chaos of Battlefield 6—otherwise known as Call of Duty: Rebooted.

Battlefield 4 delivers a complete gaming experience: moments of pure chaos balanced with stretches of calm where strategy and planning actually matter. Every shot counts, and none of that artificial bloom, no background algorithms nudging your luck. You either hit your target, or you don’t. It’s honest, raw, and absolutely brilliant.

Battlefield 4 is a large-scale first-person shooter developed by DICE and released in 2013. Built on the Frostbite 3 engine, it emphasizes massive multiplayer warfare, destructible environments, and combined-arms combat across land, sea, and air. It refines the modern military formula established by Battlefield 3 with improved visuals, smoother gameplay, and greater tactical depth.

Multiplayer is the centerpiece. Matches support up to 64 players on PC and modern consoles, blending infantry, vehicles, and aircraft in dynamic battles. The class system—Assault, Engineer, Support, and Recon—returns, encouraging teamwork through distinct roles and gadgets. The gunplay is responsive, with clear recoil patterns and a wide weapon customization system that lets players fine-tune performance for different situations.

The standout feature remains “Levolution,” where large environmental changes alter the battlefield mid-match. Skyscrapers collapse, dams break, and ships run aground, reshaping map layouts and strategies in real time. It adds unpredictability and spectacle, giving Battlefield 4 a unique identity among shooters of its era.

The campaign follows a U.S. squad caught in a geopolitical conflict involving China and Russia. It’s more cinematic than deep, offering set pieces and high production values but limited replayability. The narrative exists mainly as a tutorial for multiplayer mechanics.

Technically, Battlefield 4 launched with major performance and server issues that damaged its early reputation. However, DICE steadily patched and stabilized the game, eventually turning it into one of the most polished and reliable entries in the series. Today, it runs smoothly with strong optimization and minimal bugs.

Audio-visual presentation remains exceptional. The sound design delivers powerful immersion—gunfire, explosions, and radio chatter all feel authentic. The graphics, even years later, hold up due to strong lighting, detailed textures, and large-scale effects.

Overall, Battlefield 4 stands as one of the franchise’s best-balanced titles. It combines tight gunplay, large-scale tactics, and evolving maps into a complete and rewarding experience. Despite its rough launch, it became a benchmark for modern military shooters and remains a fan favorite for its depth, teamwork, and enduring replay value.

Battlefield 4 may look impressive on the surface, but the experience quickly falls apart thanks to its notorious launch bugs, constant server crashes, broken hit detection, and rubber-banding that makes every match feel like you’re gaming on dial-up internet. The campaign is bland, the AI is forgettable, and multiplayer often turns into chaos where vehicles dominate, snipers camp across the map, and you spend more time respawning than actually playing. Even years later, the game still suffers from inconsistent netcode and frustrating balance issues that make firefights feel unfair. Meanwhile, Black Ops 7 treated as a hypothetical future title feels like the exact opposite: fast, polished, stable, and designed with crisp gunplay, smooth movement, strong hit detection, and a progression system that actually rewards you instead of punishing your patience. Where Battlefield 4 feels messy, outdated, and unreliable, Black Ops 7 feels modern, consistent, and far more fun to jump into, giving players the tight, responsive gameplay BF4 often fails to deliver.

Now, don't let the nostalgia fool you, Battlefield 4 is worse than the ones that came before.

The story has horrible writing, it literally starts with a flash foward of you letting your squad leader drown in a car, while, on the same mission, 2 minutes before it actually happens it makes you cut his leg in a supposed "tense" moment to get him out of some debris so he doesn't die there... as if that matters or as if I forgot what happened on the start of the mission.... and it doesn't stop there, the game tries to make you feel bad and worried about your squadmates even though they have NO PERSONALITY and even though the story keeps killing characters willy nilly, [spoiler]They even show you an actual interesting character, Dima from the previous game, and he just pulls a Black Op's Reznov, gets you out of a prison and fucking dies on the end of the same mission, wow, just wow. They killed off the most interesting character in the game to do a Call Of Duty refference, on Battlefield.[/spoiler], The game actively retcons all you did in 3 saying: despite all that war still broke out LOL.
And still, it wouldn't excuse a bad review, but there's so much more...

For starters, on the badly written campaign, you are given a new mechanic, press Q to tell your squadmates shoot the designated enemies, this would have been a fresh interesting mechanic to play if it wasn't made useless by another mechanic: YOUR SQUADMATES DON'T DO DAMAGE, they don't even supress the enemy, actually, the enemy tends to ignore them and just focus you, so, on every single firefight, you have to kill every single enemy while every single enemy shoots YOU.

Even then, the campaign would still be playable if it wasn't for the fact that it is PLAGUED by bugs. When I played on console, every time i stopped playing the campaign to switch games, play multiplayer or just to turn the console off, the ENTIRE PROGRESS was reset and had to play from the very first mission. Now, on PC I'm encountering bugs that I've never seen before, phasing through the floor and falling into the void, invisible walls appearing exactly where I need to advance (sometimes, somehow, tabbing out of the game and tabbing back in fixes this), enemies not spawning (need to kill all enemies to advance a checkpoint)...

Moving to multiplayer, the only good thing I can say about it is that Levolution was a very interesting and fresh concept that works, and somehow EA has actively decided to ignore it and not use it on any other Battlefield game despite the nº1 thing that the community asks for.... (It's EA they don't know what made their games a success) and it has elevators.

Everything else in multiplayer is just a watered down version of Battlefield 3: despite the levolution, normal destruction was toned down even more, vehicles are faster and repairing is also faster, so the old problem of engineer + vehicle = unkillable was worsened. Movement was made even faster and the penalties of running, jumping and shooting were toned down to promote a faster paced combat, which makes the new mechanic, leaning from corners actually obsolete. Maps were less big and less open than on 3, they even took off runways for the airplanes so you just spawn on one on the air. Classes feel less specialized than on 3 despite keeping most gadjets, more focus on individual play. The entire game feels less grounded and more arcadey than 3

Then you have the battlepacks... the precursor of lootboxes and microtransactions, you can get them through play, but they inflated the camos for the guns, the camos for the characters, the different slots for different gun attachments... you could grind levels to get battlepacks but half of the battlepack is going to give you attachments for a gun that you don't even have yet. Want the acog sight for your favourite weapon that you use? good luck! it doesn't matter that you unlocked the acog for this rifle, this other rifle needs a whole other new acog.

It also kept the DLC tradition of BF3, selling a bajillion map dlcs, the funny thing is: they released one with maps from BF3 but reimagined and they literally just made them worse, Operation Metro on Conquest has 1 flag less, which effects the entire balance of the map. Caspian border, which was this nice, big, open map on BF3 is now a smaller map with a huge wall in a corner that interrupts all flow the original had, then they made another DLC that heavily hinted the mechs and motherships and showcased the dropships from 2142.... I'll just say that 2042 just feels like a worse insult now.

This game right here is where EA started to show that they have no idea what they are doing with their own Battlefield games, I want to believe 6 will be good but they don't even know what makes their games to succeed.

The story has horrible writing, it literally starts with a flash foward of you letting your squad leader drown in a car, while, on the same mission, 2 minutes before it actually happens it makes you cut his leg in a supposed "tense" moment to get him out of some debris so he doesn't die there... as if that matters or as if I forgot what happened on the start of the mission.... and it doesn't stop there, the game tries to make you feel bad and worried about your squadmates even though they have NO PERSONALITY and even though the story keeps killing characters willy nilly, [spoiler]They even show you an actual interesting character, Dima from the previous game, and he just pulls a Black Op's Reznov, gets you out of a prison and fucking dies on the end of the same mission, wow, just wow. They killed off the most interesting character in the game to do a Call Of Duty refference, on Battlefield.[/spoiler], The game actively retcons all you did in 3 saying: despite all that war still broke out LOL.
And still, it wouldn't excuse a bad review, but there's so much more...

For starters, on the badly written campaign, you are given a new mechanic, press Q to tell your squadmates shoot the designated enemies, this would have been a fresh interesting mechanic to play if it wasn't made useless by another mechanic: YOUR SQUADMATES DON'T DO DAMAGE, they don't even supress the enemy, actually, the enemy tends to ignore them and just focus you, so, on every single firefight, you have to kill every single enemy while every single enemy shoots YOU.

Even then, the campaign would still be playable if it wasn't for the fact that it is PLAGUED by bugs. When I played on console, every time i stopped playing the campaign to switch games, play multiplayer or just to turn the console off, the ENTIRE PROGRESS was reset and had to play from the very first mission. Now, on PC I'm encountering bugs that I've never seen before, phasing through the floor and falling into the void, invisible walls appearing exactly where I need to advance (sometimes, somehow, tabbing out of the game and tabbing back in fixes this), enemies not spawning (need to kill all enemies to advance a checkpoint)...

Moving to multiplayer, the only good thing I can say about it is that Levolution was a very interesting and fresh concept that works, and somehow EA has actively decided to ignore it and not use it on any other Battlefield game despite the nº1 thing that the community asks for.... (It's EA they don't know what made their games a success) and it has elevators.

Everything else in multiplayer is just a watered down version of Battlefield 3: despite the levolution, normal destruction was toned down even more, vehicles are faster and repairing is also faster, so the old problem of engineer + vehicle = unkillable was worsened. Movement was made even faster and the penalties of running, jumping and shooting were toned down to promote a faster paced combat, which makes the new mechanic, leaning from corners actually obsolete. Maps were less big and less open than on 3, they even took off runways for the airplanes so you just spawn on one on the air. Classes feel less specialized than on 3 despite keeping most gadjets, more focus on individual play. The entire game feels less grounded and more arcadey than 3

Then you have the battlepacks... the precursor of lootboxes and microtransactions, you can get them through play, but they inflated the camos for the guns, the camos for the characters, the different slots for different gun attachments... you could grind levels to get battlepacks but half of the battlepack is going to give you attachments for a gun that you don't even have yet. Want the acog sight for your favourite weapon that you use? good luck! it doesn't matter that you unlocked the acog for this rifle, this other rifle needs a whole other new acog.

It also kept the DLC tradition of BF3, selling a bajillion map dlcs, the funny thing is: they released one with maps from BF3 but reimagined and they literally just made them worse, Operation Metro on Conquest has 1 flag less, which effects the entire balance of the map. Caspian border, which was this nice, big, open map on BF3 is now a smaller map with a huge wall in a corner that interrupts all flow the original had, then they made another DLC that heavily hinted the mechs and motherships and showcased the dropships from 2142.... I'll just say that 2042 just feels like a worse insult now.

This game right here is where EA started to show that they have no idea what they are doing with their own Battlefield games, I want to believe 6 will be good but they don't even know what makes their games to succeed.

Battlefield 4 may look impressive on the surface, but the experience quickly falls apart thanks to its notorious launch bugs, constant server crashes, broken hit detection, and rubber-banding that makes every match feel like you’re gaming on dial-up internet. The campaign is bland, the AI is forgettable, and multiplayer often turns into chaos where vehicles dominate, snipers camp across the map, and you spend more time respawning than actually playing. Even years later, the game still suffers from inconsistent netcode and frustrating balance issues that make firefights feel unfair. Meanwhile, Black Ops 7 treated as a hypothetical future title feels like the exact opposite: fast, polished, stable, and designed with crisp gunplay, smooth movement, strong hit detection, and a progression system that actually rewards you instead of punishing your patience. Where Battlefield 4 feels messy, outdated, and unreliable, Black Ops 7 feels modern, consistent, and far more fun to jump into, giving players the tight, responsive gameplay BF4 often fails to deliver.
